case_name: State of Gujarat v. Messrs. Kailash Engineering Co.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 945 of 1965 arises from judgment and order dated December 14, 1962 of the Gujarat High Court in Sales Tax Reference No. 16 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 945 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 14, 1962 of the Gujarat High Court in Sales Tax Re- ference No. 16 of 1961.

facts.text: Messrs. Kailash Engineering Co. is an engineering company having workshop at Morvi on the meter gauge section of the Western Railway.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Kailash Engineering Co.  hereinafter referred to as the respondent  was an engineering companycern having their workshop at Morvi on the meter gauge section of the Western Railway.

facts.text: Respondent obtained contract from Western Railway Administration for construction of III class passenger coaches on certain conditions of tender.

anchor.surface_text: They obtained a companytract from the Western Railway Administration for companystruction of III class passenger companyches on certain companyditions described as the companyditions of tender.

facts.text: Contract was reduced to writing and described as an agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Under that companytract which was reduced to writing and was described as an agreement, the respondent companystructed three companyches

facts.text: Respondent constructed three coaches.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent companystructed three companyches and submitted a bill which was properly certified in accordance with the agreement by the Railway Administration on October 4, 1958.

facts.text: Bill was certified by Railway Administration on October 4, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and submitted a bill which was properly certified in accordance with the agreement by the Railway Administration on October 4, 1958.

facts.text: Net value of work done certified at Rs. 1,22,035/-

anchor.surface_text: The net value of the work done by the respondent was certified at Rs. 1,22,035/-. After receipt of this money,

facts.text: Respondent received the money.

anchor.surface_text: After receipt of this money, the respondent wrote to the Additional Collector of Sales Tax requesting him under S. 27

facts.text: Respondent requested Additional Collector under S. 27 of Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953 to hold it was works contract not sale.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent wrote to the Additional Collector of Sales Tax requesting him under S. 27 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953, to hold that this was a works companytract, and that the transaction, in respect of which the respondent received the money, did number amount to a sale,

facts.text: Additional Collector held transaction covered by bill dated October 4, 1958 is a sale and tax payable.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Collector held that two questions fell for determination before him Whether the transaction companyered by the bill dated 4th October, 1958, is a sale and  2  if it is a sale, whether any tax is payable in respect of the same. The Additional Collector answered both the questions in the affirmative against the respondent.

facts.text: Appeal before Gujarat Sales Tax Tribunal failed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal before the Gujarat Sales Tax Tribunal failed and thereupon, the respondent sought a reference to the High Court of Gujarat.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court: whether work under Contract Certificates No. M/60 1 B-PRTN dated 4th October, 1958 for building 3 B.G. Coaches over chassis supplied by Railway is works contract or sale.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal referred the following question for the opinion of the High Court- Whether on a proper companystruction of the agreement as a whole and its general companyditions and specification, the work done and companyered by Contract Certificates No. M/60 1  B-PRTN, dated 4th October, 1958, for the perfor- mance of the works of building, erecting and furnishing 3 B. G. Coaches over the chassis supplied by the Railway is a works companytract number amounting to sale, or whether it is a transaction of sale.

facts.text: High Court held transaction was works contract not sale.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in favour of the respondent, holding that the transaction was a works companytract carried out by the respondent and did number amount to a sale.

facts.text: State of Gujarat appealed challenging High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, this appeal has been brought up by the State of Gujarat challenging the companyrectness of the decision of the High Court.

facts.text: Contract provision: ownership in plant and materials vests in Railway as soon as brought to site.

anchor.surface_text: though there was a provision in one of the clauses of the agreement that as soon as the plant and materials were brought on the site where the companyches were to be companystructed, the ownership in them would vest in the Railway,

facts.text: Tribunal held ownership passed only when completed and handed over.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal held that the ownership in those materials never passed to the Railway because of the indication given by another clause which provided that on removal of companytractor or on rescission of companytract, the Railway Authorities would be entitled to take possession and retain all materials,... On this basis, the Tribunal held that, from the general companyditions of the companytract, it appeared that the ownership of the companych bodies only passed to the Railway when companypleted and handed over to the Railway,

facts.text: High Court found contract for work of building, erecting and furnishing coach bodies on Broad Gauge underframes belonging to Railway.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, in its judgment, reproduced the preamble of the companytract as well as a large number of clauses of it to show that in the companytract, at every stage, it was clearly mentioned that the companytract was for performance of work of building, erecting and furnishing companych bodies on Broad Gauge underframes which already belonged to the Railway.

facts.text: Ownership in materials vests in Railway as soon as brought to site of construction.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the companytract showed that as soon as the materials were taken by the respondent to the site of companystruction of the companyches, the ownership in those materials vested in the Railway

facts.text: Property in ready coach bodies vested in Railway automatically without further transfer.

anchor.surface_text: and all that the respondent had to do was to carry out the work of erecting and furnishing the companych bodies. When the companych bodies were ready, the property in them vested in the Railway automatically without any further transfer of rights in it to the Railway.

facts.text: Ownership in ready coach bodies did not vest in respondent at all.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the ownership in the ready companych bodies did number vest in the respondent at all.

facts.text: Respondent obtained materials and brought to site, acting as agent for Railway.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, the materials for building the companych bodies had to be obtained by the respondent and brought to the site of companystruction, but the provision that the ownership in those materials would vest in the Railway as soon as those materials were brought to the site clearly indicated that the respondent, in purchasing those materials, was acting more or less in the capacity of an agent for the Railway.

facts.text: If materials destroyed or damaged at site, risk borne by Railway.

anchor.surface_text: While the materials were at site, the effect of vesting of their ownership in the Railway was that if they were destroyed or damaged, the risk had to be borne by the Railway, even though the Railway might have been entitled to reimburse itself,

facts.text: Clause 29 provides contractor liable for loss, stolen, injured or destroyed materials despite ownership in Railway.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, under clause 29, there was a specific provision for the companytingency that the materials or plant may be lost, stolen, injured or destroyed by fire, tempest or otherwise. This special provision was to the effect that the liability of the companytractor was number to be diminished in any way, number was the Railway to be in any way answerable for loss or damage on the happening of such companytingency.

facts.text: High Court found contract entire and indivisible for carrying out works, not sale of materials or coach bodies.

anchor.surface_text: Taking into account all the terms of the companytract as a whole, the High Court came to the finding that the companytract between the parties was one entire and indivisible companytract for carrying out the works specified in full details in the agreement, and that it did number envisage either the sale of materials by the respondent to the Railway, or of the companych bodies as such.

facts.text: Supreme Court held transaction is works contract not involving sale.

anchor.surface_text: Here, we find that all the terms of the companytract lead to the only inference that the respondent was number to be the owner of the ready companych bodies and that the property in those bodies vested in the Railway even during the process of companystruction. This was, therefore, clearly a works companytract which did number involve any sale.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The decision given by the High Court was companyrect. The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 14, 1962 of the Gujarat High Court in Sales Tax Re- ference No. 16 of 1961.
This appeal under special leave granted by this Court arises out of proceedings for assessment of sales-tax under the Bombay Sales Tax Act III of 1953.

under the Bombay Sales Tax Act III of 1953. Messrs. Kailash Engineering Co.  hereinafter referred to as the respondent  was an engineering companycern having their workshop at Morvi on the meter gauge section of the Western Railway.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court and Supreme Court held it was works contract not sale.

arguments.claim: Ownership in materials never passed to Railway until coach bodies completed and handed over, so contract for supply of coach bodies amounting to sale.

anchor.surface_text: though there was a provision in one of the clauses of the agreement that as soon as the plant and materials were brought on the site where the coaches were to be constructed, the ownership in them would vest in the Railway, the Tribunal held that the ownership in those materials never passed to the Railway because of the indication given by another clause which provided that on removal of contractor or on rescission of contract,

arguments.court_reasoning: Ownership vested immediately on bringing materials to site; contract for work on Railway property.

arguments.claim: Contract is for performance of work of building, erecting and furnishing coach bodies on Broad Gauge underframes belonging to Railway; ownership vests in materials on site arrival and in completed bodies automatically.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, in its judgment, reproduced the preamble of the contract as well as a large number of clauses of it to show that in the contract, at every stage, it was clearly mentioned that the contract was for performance of work of building, erecting and furnishing coach bodies on Broad Gauge underframes which already belonged to the Railway.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to be in charge of the respondent during companystruction, a special provision had to be made making the respondent responsible for the loss and throw

arguments.court_reasoning: All terms confirm works contract; property vests without transfer.

arguments.claim: Contract is entire and indivisible for carrying out works, does not envisage sale of materials or coach bodies.

anchor.surface_text: Taking into account all the terms of the contract as a whole, the High Court came to the finding that the contract between the parties was one entire and indivisible contract for carrying out the works specified in full details in the agreement, and that it did not envisage either the sale of materials by the respondent to the Railway, or of the coach bodies as such.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to be in charge of the respondent during companystruction, a special provision had to be made making the respondent responsible for the loss and throw

arguments.court_reasoning: Terms lead to inference respondent not owner; works contract.

arguments.claim: The transaction amounts to a sale similar to supply of bus bodies in Patnaik & Co. v. State of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, learned counsel for the appellant relied on the decision of this Court in Patnaik & Co. v. State of Orissa.  1  In that particular case, the contract in question was for the supply of bus bodies, and it was held that when the bus bodies were supplied by the contractor and money received by him, it amounted to a sale.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to get the balance of the work done by another agency and recover the difference in companyt from the body builder and for this, purpose, the Controll

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts differ markedly: here coach bodies not supplied as units, ownership vested early, unfinished bodies Railway property, special liability clause.

arguments.claim: Ownership in materials vests in Railway as soon as brought to site; respondent acted as agent in purchasing; property in completed bodies vests automatically without transfer.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the contract showed that as soon as the materials were taken by the respondent to the site of construction of the coaches, the ownership in those materials vested in the Railway and all that the respondent had to do was to carry out the work of erecting and furnishing the coach bodies.

arguments.claim: Risk of destruction/damage to materials at site borne by Railway due to ownership vesting, despite contractor custody.

anchor.surface_text: While the materials were at site, the effect of vesting of their ownership in the Railway was that if they were destroyed or damaged, the risk had to be borne by the Railway, even though the Railway might have been entitled to reimburse itself,

arguments.claim: Clause 29 imposes liability on contractor for loss despite ownership in Railway, necessary because contractor in possession.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, under clause 29, there was a specific provision for the contingency that the materials or plant may be lost, stolen, injured or destroyed by fire, tempest or otherwise. This special provision was to the effect that the liability of the contractor was not to be diminished in any way, nor was the Railway to be in any way answerable for loss or damage on the happening of such contingency.

arguments.claim: Patnaik case distinguishable: (1) coach bodies not described as units to supply; (2) unfinished bodies Railway property from start, not seized; (3) special provision for contractor liability despite ownership.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, appears that the facts and circumstances, on the basis of which the Court gave that opinion, do not find place in the case... Thus, the terms of the contract in this case are markedly different from those which came up for consideration in that case.

arguments.claim: All contract terms show respondent not owner of ready coach bodies; property vested in Railway during construction; hence works contract not involving sale.

anchor.surface_text: Here, we find that all the terms of the contract lead to the only inference that the respondent was not to be the owner of the ready coach bodies and that the property in those bodies vested in the Railway even during the process of construction. This was, therefore, clearly a works contract which did not involve any sale.

holdings.text: all the terms of the contract lead to the only inference that the respondent was not to be the owner of the ready coach bodies and that the property in those bodies vested in the Railway even during the process of construction. This was, therefore, clearly a works contract which did not involve any sale.

anchor.surface_text: Here, we find that all the terms of the companytract lead to the only inference that the respondent was number to be the owner of the ready companych bodies and that the property in those bodies vested in the Railway even during the process of companystruction. This was, therefore, clearly a works companytract which did number involve any sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construing entire contract harmoniously, ownership vests in Railway from materials arrival through construction without transfer from respondent; distinguishes Patnaik precedent.

holdings.text: The decision given by the High Court was correct. The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The decision given by the High Court was companyrect. The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly held transaction as works contract based on contract terms analysis affirmed by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: as soon as the materials were taken by the respondent to the site of construction of the coaches, the ownership in those materials vested in the Railway

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the companytract showed that as soon as the materials were taken by the respondent to the site of companystruction of the companyches, the ownership in those materials vested in the Railway

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of contract clause on vesting of ownership upon arrival at site.

holdings.text: When the coach bodies were ready, the property in them vested in the Railway automatically without any further transfer of rights in it to the Railway.

anchor.surface_text: and all that the respondent had to do was to carry out the work of erecting and furnishing the companych bodies. When the companych bodies were ready, the property in them vested in the Railway automatically without any further transfer of rights in it to the Railway.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract terms provide for automatic vesting upon completion without need for transfer indicating no sale.

holdings.text: the ownership in the ready coach bodies did not vest in the respondent at all.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the ownership in the ready companych bodies did number vest in the respondent at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with immediate vesting clauses throughout contract performance.

holdings.text: the respondent, in purchasing those materials, was acting more or less in the capacity of an agent for the Railway.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, the materials for building the companych bodies had to be obtained by the respondent and brought to the site of companystruction, but the provision that the ownership in those materials would vest in the Railway as soon as those materials were brought to the site clearly indicated that the respondent, in purchasing those materials, was acting more or less in the capacity of an agent for the Railway.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Immediate vesting upon site arrival implies agency rather than sale.

holdings.text: the terms of the contract in this case are markedly different from those which came up for consideration in that case.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, appears that the facts and circumstances, on the basis of which the Court gave that opinion, do number find place in the case... Thus, the terms of the companytract in this case are markedly different from those which came up for companysideration in that case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three key differences: no unit supply description, early property vesting without seizure, special liability clause despite ownership.

holdings.text: the contract between the parties was one entire and indivisible contract for carrying out the works specified in full details in the agreement, and that it did not envisage either the sale of materials by the respondent to the Railway, or of the coach bodies as such.

anchor.surface_text: Taking into account all the terms of the companytract as a whole, the High Court came to the finding that the companytract between the parties was one entire and indivisible companytract for carrying out the works specified in full details in the agreement, and that it did number envisage either the sale of materials by the respondent to the Railway, or of the companych bodies as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of all terms shows indivisible works contract affirmed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Taking into account all the terms of the companytract as a whole, the High Court came to the finding that the companytract between the parties was one entire and indivisible companytract for carrying out the works specified in full details in the agreement, and that it did number envisage either the sale of materials by the respondent to the Railway, or of the companych bodies as such.
The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
